Expectation1: Provide guidance and wisdom based on life experience
Situation1: A grandchild directly asks their grandfather for help and advice with a serious concern in their life.
Expectation2: Deliver packages on time and to the correct address
Situation2: A medical supply delivery must reach a hospital department on schedule to ensure patient care
Story:
My phone buzzed just as I was about to leave for my next delivery—a medical supply run to the hospital, one marked urgent in bold red letters. I glanced at the time, feeling the familiar pressure of the ticking clock. As I reached for my keys, my grandson called out from the living room, his voice trembling. “Grandpa, can I talk to you? It’s important.” He looked up at me, eyes wide and searching, holding back tears. I knew that look; he needed more than a quick answer. He needed the kind of guidance only a grandfather could give, the kind that comes from years of mistakes and hard-won wisdom.

But the hospital was waiting, and I knew the consequences if I was late. Patients depended on those supplies, and my job was to make sure they arrived on time, every time. My supervisor’s words echoed in my mind: “No delays, especially not with medical deliveries.” I felt torn, my heart pulled in two directions—toward the boy who needed me, and the patients who didn’t even know my name but counted on me all the same. I stood frozen, keys in hand, caught between the expectations of a loving grandfather and a responsible delivery person.
